items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Today, Saturday 05/11/2022, is forecast to be a showery day and the lake level at the Lodore gauge is expected to keep receding. However the lake will remain high for at least the next few days, with further rain forecast over the next few days. Flooding is affecting locations near these rivers and the lake, with low lying land most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 06/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further light rainfall is forecast this morning, with heavier more persistent rain tomorrow.
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there remains a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further rainfall is forecast early morning, Saturday, 5/11/2022 so we expect river levels to remain high. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded; refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 5/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels in Buxted and Uckfield have now fallen to nearer normal, following Friday morning's heavy rain. River levels in Isfield are steadily falling and should be near to normal by Saturday morning. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads. Friday evening should remain dry and only a small amount of rain is forecast for Saturday. However, further heavy rain (25mm) is currently forecast for Sunday (06/11/2022), which could cause some more flooding along the River Uck. Please keep flood protection products installed, or close by, if you have them. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels have fallen at Forest Row, Summerford Bridge, near Withyham and at Colliersland Bridge near Ashurst. The internal flooding of property is not expected.  Patchy rain is due on Saturday evening and heavier rainfall is due on Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will probably be maintained throughout the weekend. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly around Forest Row, Ashurst and Penshurst and around Balls Green at Ashurst. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers in advance of Sundays rain. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday 5 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  
Further rainfall is expected today and overnight into Sunday 06/11/2022. This may cause river levels to rise again and we will re-issue this flood alert if required.
Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens, and we continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are now falling steadily on the River Adur and will continue to fall as Saturday continues (05/11/2022). Flood impacts to the A281 at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury, should reduce throughout Saturday, leaving less water in fields and gardens near Mock Bridge. 10mm of rain is forecast across Saturday (05/11/2022) which could lead to a slight rise in river levels. For twelve hours, from 03:00 Sunday morning (06/11/2022), localised heavy showers of 25mm are forecast which may see further river level rise. Unsettled conditions will continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable if those heavy showers occur. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 19:00 on 05/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains high but is now falling at Alverstone and Sandown. Residual flood impacts are expected to be affecting land, footpaths and cycle tracks. Minor impact flooding will continue to affect Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Today (05/11/2022), showers are forecast. These are not expected to cause the river to rise again but may keep the level high for longer. On Sunday (06/11/2022), heavier showers are forecast. If these affect the Eastern Yar, it could cause the river to rise again to the level recorded Friday (04/11/2022). Further showers are expected on Monday and Tuesday. We have been operating the sluice at Bembridge to manage water levels across Brading marshes. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remain prepared for continued flood impacts throughout the next few days. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Saturday 05/11/2022.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain above flood alert threshold on the River Blackwater as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads, footpaths and farmland is expected today, especially in the Swallowfield area. 
This mornings forecast is for more showers, with some more persistent rain tomorrow, therefore levels will fall today but rise again tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, 05/11/22, or if the situation changes.

River levels along the Ouse are now falling steadily following a dry Friday evening. Minor flood impacts will continue at Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and areas of Barcombe Mills but should reduce as Saturday continues (05/11/2022). 10mm of rain is forecast across Saturday which should see limited impacts on river fall. However, localised heavy showers of 25mm are forecast for Sunday (06/11/2022) which may see river levels rise. Unsettled conditions could continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022). Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products should be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 18:00 05/11/2022.

River levels are now falling steadily on the Cuckmere River in Alfriston following a dry Friday evening and will continue to fall as Saturday continues (05/11/2022). Flood impacts may now be reducing at The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers through Hellingly are now nearing normal levels. 10mm of rain is forecast across Saturday (05/11/2022), which could cause a small rise in river levels in Hellingly and slow the fall in Alfriston. For twelve hours from 03:00 Sunday morning (06/11/2022), localised heavy showers of 25mm are forecast which may see river levels rise. Unsettled conditions could continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022). Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston and keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are now falling gradually at all locations in the Rother valley. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is due on Saturday evening and heavier rainfall is due on Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will probably be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane and along the river Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers in advance of Sundays rain. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday 5 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Leatherhead and Cobham areas. The risk of flooding to roads and low lying land remains for today 05/11/2022.
Further rainfall is expected today and overnight into Sunday 06/11/2022.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please remain aware of your local situation.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 06/11/2022.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: River levels are now falling steadily on the River Adur and will continue to fall throughout Saturday (05/11/2022). Flood impacts to the A281 at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury, should reduce throughout Saturday, leaving less water in fields and gardens near Mock Bridge. 10mm of rain is forecast across Saturday (05/11/2022) which could lead to a slight rise in river levels. For twelve hours, from 03:00 Sunday morning (06/11/2022), localised heavy showers of 25mm are forecast which may see further river level rise. Unsettled conditions will continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable if those heavy showers occur. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if our confidence increases of property flooding.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. River levels have fallen at locations between Yalding and Allington Lock, including Maidstone. Internal flooding of property is not expected.  Patchy rain is due on Saturday evening and heavier rainfall is due on Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will probably be maintained throughout the weekend. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly riverside areas of Maidstone and along the River Medway around Aylesford. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers in advance of Sundays rain. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday 5 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are now falling steadily following a dry Friday evening and will continue to reduce as Saturday continues (05/11/2022). Flood impacts should now be reducing at Barcombe Mills and at the Anchor Inn, Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane. Flood water impacts will also reduce in fields across the day. A Flood Alert remains in force for these minor impacts. 10mm of rain is forecast across Saturday (05/11/2022) which should see limited impacts on river levels falling. However, localised heavy showers of 25mm are forecast for Sunday (06/11/2022) which could see river levels rise. Unsettled conditions could continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022). Please consider keeping flood protection products installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

River levels are now falling steadily on the Cuckmere River in Alfriston, following a dry Friday evening and will continue to fall as Saturday continues (05/11/2022). Flood impacts may now be reducing at The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane. A Flood Alert remains in force for these minor impacts. 10mm of rain is forecast across Saturday (05/11/2022) which could slow the fall of the river. For twelve hours, from 03:00 Sunday morning (06/11/2022), localised heavy showers of 25mm are forecast which may see river levels rise. Unsettled conditions could continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022). Please remain prepared for the possibility of further flooding on Sunday (06/11/2022). Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston and keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Warning if the risk of flooding increases significantly.

The river level has dropped below the level of Flood Alert. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
No further rainfall is forecast until tomorrow (Saturday 5th November)
There may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are falling in the Lingfield and Haxted Mill areas but are still rising gently in the Edenbridge, Hever and at Vexour. Minor flood impacts are still expected. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is due on Saturday evening and heavier rainfall is due on Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will probably be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers in advance of Sundays rain.

This message will be updated by 8pm on Saturday 5 November 2022, or as the situation changes.
